instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
This board has been through a fire!  Family friend just lost everything in a fire. I was able to retrieve the Data off of the ssd and thought I'd see if I get good karma and try and fix the Macbook too.  It looks like there is no actual fire damage just water damage.  I've put it through the Crest and afterwards it did show the low battery connected symbol but now I tried giving it some power to work on it and nothing.  

Q. Is there a sticky topic on trouble shooting power issues?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: I'm going to check the one-wire circuit and it does have an green then orange light on power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Well I guess first off I will test the MagSafe.  My schematics say 18.5v but I'm only getting 16.5v on PIN 1 and 3.6v on Adapter Sense Pin 6.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Ok well I just happened to have another Macbook same model come in and at the magsafe on logic board the voltage is 16.5v.  I guess that's normal for schematics to be off that much?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Onewire is fine you have a green/orange light. 3V on L7560 present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Yes I have 3v on L7560

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>   = 12.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>       = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 3.4v

Also I no longer get the dead battery symbol when jumping the power on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: I watched a video where Louis was trouble shooting a board with no Green/orange light and he tested the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>  ( S3 meaning sleep, correct? ) and he got 5v on that rail.   How did he get the board to be in a sleep state to test if there was 5V when the board was not powering on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: This board should auto power on after battery was disconnected. Check <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> carefully, it may be pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>.  Alright now where do I start to track that down?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4v

Just no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>.    I wonder if I could have been an idiot and zapped something when I was trying to jump the power on at SMC on and off.  I might have accidentally touched <SIGNAL>SMC_MANUAL_RST</SIGNAL> with power.  I'm shakey with my hands sometimes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: The enable for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> both come from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, so check again what is there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Ok so I've checked but I'm not that great with schematics I guess because all I can find is <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_RIO</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3RSO_ALCAM</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_ALSCAM</SIGNAL>, etc.  No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> alone.  And I can't even figure out where <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> starts to check that component.  I know how to put <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> into Open BoardView and see all the points but that does't help if I can't trace down the path.  Thank for all the help do you happen to know the first component to check for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: So if <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> then where does it do that because I can't seem to find that on the schematics?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Ok thanks for that now I see that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> is not there.  Ok so I have to figure out what makes those which as you tell me comes from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.  Ok so now to see where that starts. When searching a schematic for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> I get 5 pages that have it.  Is the first page where it starts and is that true of other lines when searching schematics?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: I guess my question is.. how do I figure out where something is going when I'm switching pages.  Just hit the next button on the search? Thx for the help and sorry if that's a stupid question.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
Lets start over with this. 
Are you using a REAL 60W charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
Yes I always use real chargers with correct wattage. I've made that mistake before. Arggg ha ha let's not start over. I'm just getting the hang of where to look.  LOL!  I think I kinda get how to read the schematics now. I see the little page numbers at the end of a line and it looks like that is where those lines go to. so I can now follow the schematic. Also nothings changed other than there is no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>. So let's not start over.  What gives power to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>?  You said <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> .   Ok so let's look at that. Looks like system power management maybe? 

I have:
Orange/Green light

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.4v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.4v

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 0v (measured at Pin 1 of L4001 and many other places)

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0v

If I can get a direction to go for I'm happy to do the research.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> cames from PCH........
Check <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>-03, voltage on both pins for all resistors (4).....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: OMG I think I might actually be learning something.. ha I was going to check there!  Yay brain cells!  Thx

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR> PIN 1. 3.34  PIN 2 = 3.33
<RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR> PIN 1 = 3.34 PIN 2 = 2.98 (it moves from that to 3.03)  is that considered pulsing or just my shaky hands?
<RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR> PIN 1 = 3.33 PIN2 = 3.23
<RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> PIN1 = 3.34 PIN 2 = 3.33

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: PPBUS is too low, check again it should be 12.56V. This indicates an issue with the SMC at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Ah ok off in search of SMC.!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: F7140 I'm getting 12.53 for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.  Not 12.4 as I posted earlier.  Is that still too low.  Seems like 12.6v is what I want but that seems pretty close.  If it is the SMC do you think it's worth reflowing because it might just be some corrosion.  I've seen what it take to replace an SMC and I don't think I want to do that.  If 12.53 for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is good then it's back to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> not being created.  So what component creates those?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Should I try bypassing the SMC? I've seen posts about that.  IF so how would I do that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Hi thanks for all you help. I tested F7140 and I get 12.53V for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: 12.53 is ok for PPBUS. RTC looks fine, so this must give a pulse on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> when power is applied, check carefully pulses will be very short and best seen on a scope.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: I don't have a scope but I can see the voltage move from 0V to .01V in a pulsing pattern.  Sorry for not having a scope that's my next purchase.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Same pulsing on CPU Vcore?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: I see from another post where <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> rails are missing that <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> was shorted to ground.  Now I know that this board is not that board and who knows what's shorted but should I be looking for a certain rail that's shorted to ground? Thanks so much for your help Duke.  I feel like this board is being a devote christian on the first date. It's really gonna take some time to score.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Yes is <SIGNAL>S0_CPU</SIGNAL> pulsing? What areas were liquid damaged?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Hey Duke thanks again for the help.  My mom can't wait for me to fix something so that I'll move out of her garage. I'm turning 40 this week so........ anyways the whole damn board was hit with a firehose. No really it was from a fire. It didn't get hot and there was no black marks on it.  The board looked like a bucket full of shit but after the crest cleaning it did show me the battery dead symbol and after that I couldn't get it to boot.   I realize this might be a dead end but I'm really learning so much and you are the man!  Also it worked just for a second arg!  I'd really like to know what the pulse signifies.  Is that a pulse to switch states or is it a short to ground pulse?  My mom says she'll bake you extra special cookies.  I just wish she'd put on a shirt.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
If any power rails does not come high in the specified time the power up sequence will start over again. This also happens when the ROM cannot be read, clock signals are missing or pretty much any other reason. Pulsing power can therefore be anything.
Most likely areas of corrosion are around SPI ROM and clock chip or <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. There is no easy diagnostic for this problem and even for me would not be an easy repair.
